summary:
The Security Council,
 Reaffirming previous resolutions on Afghanistan, particularly 1378 (2001) and 1383 (2001), 
Supporting international efforts to combat terrorism, 
Welcoming developments in Afghanistan for all Afghans to enjoy rights and freedom, 
Recognizing Afghan responsibility for providing security and law and order, 
Reiterating endorsement of the Bonn Agreement, 
Noting the request for an international security force, 
Welcoming the UK offer to lead the force, 
Stressing adherence to human rights and humanitarian law, 
Reaffirming commitment to Afghanistan's sovereignty and unity, 
Determining the situation in Afghanistan still threatens international peace and security, 
 Authorizes for 6 months an International Security Assistance Force to assist the Afghan Interim Authority in maintaining security in Kabul and surrounding areas. 
 Calls upon Member States to contribute personnel, equipment and resources to the Force. 
 Authorizes participating Member States to take necessary measures to fulfil the Force's mandate. 
 Calls upon the Force to work in close consultation with the Afghan Interim Authority and the Special Representative of the Secretary-General. 
 Calls upon all Afghans to cooperate with the Force and relevant organizations. 
 Takes note of the Afghan parties' pledge to withdraw military units from Kabul and calls for its implementation. 
 Encourages neighbouring States and Member States to provide assistance to the Force. 
 Stresses expenses of the Force will be borne by participating Member States.
The Security Council:
 
Requests the International Security Assistance Force leadership to provide periodic reports through the Secretary-General on progress towards its mandate implementation;
 Calls on participating Member States to assist the Afghan Interim Authority in establishing and training new Afghan security and armed forces;
Decides to remain actively seized of the matter.
